citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Percent Large, Medium, and Small Natural Areas for the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract:
This EnviroAtlas dataset contains the percentage of small, medium, and large natural areas for each Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) 12-Digit Hydrologic Unit Code (HUC-12) of the conterminous United States that is considered Natural based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). The percentage of natural area is by size class: Small is <500 acres, Medium is 500-25,000 acres, and Large is > 25,000 acres. Natural land cover combines NLCD-CDL 63, 83, 87, 111, 112, 131, 141, 142, 143, 151, 152, 171, 190, 195.
This dataset was produced by the Tetra Tech, Inc. to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose: This EnviroAtlas dataset allows the user to join the results of data analyses showing the sizes of natural areas for the total drainage area to the WBD HUC12 GIS file for subsequent display or analyses. The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.
descript.supplinf:
This EnviroAtlas dataset is based on data originally developed using a version of the Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD 2011) extracted for EnviroAtlas on March 22, 2011. In 2015, EnviroAtlas transitioned from the WBD 2011 to a newer version - the National Hydrography Dataset Plus (NHDPlus) V2 WBD Snapshot, EnviroAtlas version - which includes updated 12-digit HUC boundaries for the Conterminous United States.
This EnviroAtlas dataset was created by reallocating the original WBD 2011 dataset to the NHDPlus V2 WBD Snapshot using area-weighted reallocation. The area weighting process assumes that values are distributed evenly across HUCs. In cases where values are unevenly distributed within a HUC, this can result in misallocated values in the new dataset. Therefore, users should exercise caution when interpreting this data, especially in regions where there are significant changes to the 12-digit HUCs. The majority of spatial changes between the two 12-digit HUC versions took place along the California coast, in Minnesota, and along the US-Canada border, especially in New England. Metric values for most of the rest of the United States are essentially unchanged. If the user is interested in data for a specific small area, especially in areas that were modified, using the original WBD 2011 version of this dataset joined with the WBD 2011 boundary feature class should provide accurate metric values. As new versions of the dataset are developed using the 2015 HUCs, these will replace the reallocated datasets in EnviroAtlas.
Before reallocating the metrics, edits were made to the area of some 12-digit HUCs. For example, along the coast of California some 12-digit HUCs had stopped at the coastline in the WBD 2011 dataset but were extended into the ocean in the NHDPlus V2 dataset. Instead of reallocating the metrics using the total area of the NHDPlus V2 HUCs, the land area based on National Land Cover Database (NLCD) 2011 was used to update the land area values. This ensured the land area of the NHDPlus V2 HUCs roughly matched the land area of the WBD 2011 HUCs. This method helped avoid incorrectly distributing terrestrial metrics, such as including the new ocean-extended area in the denominator of values that were originally calculated using land-only area as the denominator, which would result in artificially lowering the values of per-unit area metrics in the ocean-extended HUCs.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html

procstep.procdesc: The polygon version of the WBD HUC12 (provided by EPA, ORD, Landscape Ecology Group, March 2011 version) was converted to raster to increase efficiency and accuracy of subsequent runs of "Zonal Stats as Table" processing performed for the EnviroAtlas HUC-12 scale metric outputs. The first processing step was to select manually select by bounding HUC-12 units that generally coincided with the CDL raster. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.

The "Dissolve" tool was run using the field name, "HUC_12," to make multipart features using the GUI of "Dissolve." This resulted in multipart features for all duplicate "HUC_12" ID's that existed whenever a HUC-12 was not physically connected, such as on certain coast lines and large water bodies. The Dissolve Tool process eliminated the duplicates as rows in a table, but kept the geometry of the features intact. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.

A "Unique_ID" field was created for the ascending order of "OBJECTID," the primary key in an ESRI ArcGIS geodatabase. This shortened the digits representing an ID from 12 to 5 digits. The ID truncation was necessary for the future processing steps of joining and embedding CDL data into HUC12 ID's in the VALUE field using raster datasets. This process was done using the "AutoIncrement" add-on, v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.

The WBD HUC12 was converted to raster with the "Polygon to Raster" tool. Created using "Unique_ID" as the "Value" field, cell assignment type MAXIMUM_AREA, snapped to the raster "sum_comppct_r2_hydric," Cell size: "sum_comppct_r2_hydric," producing perfect agreement for accurate Zonal Statistics results as well as accurate raster processing with both SSURGO soil layers and the CDL, which both share alignment and cell size. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
The CDL codes in the raster's "Value" field were embedded into the HUC12 raster (HUC12CDL). "Raster Calculator": (HUC-12*1000) + CDL. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
A "Raster Attribute Table" was created in v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Used "Field Calculator" to create two new fields in the HUC12CDL combined raster, "Unique_ID," ([Value] -Right( [Value],3 ))/1000 and "CDL," Right( [Value],3 ). v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.

"Reclass" HUC12CDL in Arc GIS GUI Python Window into a binary classification of Natural Areas (NatCDL). 0 = Not natural, 1 = natural. 1 = CDL 63, 83, 87, 111, 112, 131, 141, 142, 143, 151, 152, 171, 190, 195. Reclassify Ncdl_nlcd VALUE "0 62 0;63 63 1;64 82 0;83 1;84 86 0;87 1;88 110 0;111 112 1;113 130 0;131 171 1;172 189 0;190 195 1;196 255 0" v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
"Raster Calculator:"(HUC12CDL * NatCDL), results in the dropping out of all non-natural CDL codes. All not natural CDL codes equal 0. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Use "Split Raster" Tool on H12CDLNAT. 4 x 4, Creates 16 Rasters of equal size. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
"Split Raster" Tool: Split Rasters 5, 6, 8, 9, 10 of previous split to create more manageable data in these zones. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Manually created a GRID polyline following the Split Rasters Borders in "Editor." v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Use "Merge" tool on the GRID border polyline to create one feature for the polyline. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Select HUC-12 polygons by "Select by Location", intersecting GRID border polyline and HUC-12. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Use "Export" to export selected border HUC-12 polygon files to new layer from right clicking layer in the table of contents. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Use "Clip" tool to clip selected border HUC-12 polygons from the multiple polygon zones. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Use "Raster to Polygon" tool by HUC-12 on all 30 Zone Rasters. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
"Export" multiple HUC-12 zones into a geodatabase. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
"Export" border HUC-12 polygons into a geodatabase. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
Use "Select by Attribute" for all zones for GRIDCODE > 0 (Natural). v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.

"Join" selected HUC-12 to zone polygon files by "Unique_ID." This will select for HUC-12s that cross over the border but have no present natural areas intersecting the border, or the HUC-12 is on both sides of the border, but not intersecting the border, due to the removal of natural areas. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
"Dissolve" tool border HUC-12 polygon files by Unique_ID. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
"Merge" tool border HUC-12 polygon files. v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.

Tables were exported as .txt files and imported into a Microsoft Access Database. The areas were calculated to get a percentage for each class. Results of each zone were appended so that all HUC-12 areas were present.
Summed fields NATCLASS0 (Less than 50 Acres), NATCLASS1, (50 to 250 Acres), and NATCLASS2 (250 to 500 Acres) to obtain percent small natural areas
Summed fields NATCLASS3 (500 to 2,500 Acres), NATCLASS4, (2,500 to 5,000 Acres), and NATCLASS5, (5,000 to 25,000 Acres) to find percent medium natural areas
Summed fields NATCLASS6 (25,000 to 50,000 Acres) and NATCLASS7 (Greater than 50,000 Acres) to find percent large natural areas.
Multiplied values for small, medium, and large natural areas by 100 to convert from decimal values to percentages.
Reallocated values from the original March 22 2011 WBD to the NHDPlus V2 WBD Snapshot, EnviroAtlas version for the Conterminous United States using area-weighted redistribution.

enttyp.enttypd: This table contains the percentage of each for each Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) 12-Digit Hydrologic Unit Code (HUC-12) of the conterminous United States that is considered Natural based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). The percentage of natural area is by size class: Small is <500 acres, Medium is 500-25,000 acres, and Large is > 25,000 acres. Natural land cover combines NLCD-CDL 63, 83, 87, 111, 112, 131, 141, 142, 143, 151, 152, 171, 190, 195.

attr.attrdef: Twelve Digit Hydrologic Unit Code. This field provides a unique 12-digit code for each subwatershed. Numbers were assigned in an upstream to downstream fashion. Where no downstream/upstream relationship could be determined, numbers were assigned in a clockwise fashion.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary Dataset; Chapter 3 of Section A; Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3.

attr.attrdef: Percent small patches of natural land cover (<500 acres) in 12-digit HUC.
Percent medium patches of natural land cover (500 - 25,000 acres) in 12-digit HUC.
Percent large patches of natural land cover (>25,000 acres) in 12-digit HUC.

overview.eaover:
For more information about EnviroAtlas data, go to https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets.
This dataset contains the percentage of small, medium, and large natural areas for each Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) 12-Digit Hydrologic Unit Code (HUC-12) (March 2011) of the conterminous United States. Natural areas are defined using the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) (2006). The percentage of natural area is by size class: Small is <500 acres, Medium is 500-25,000 acres, and Large is > 25,000 acres. Natural land cover combines NLCD-CDL 63, 83, 87, 111, 112, 131, 141, 142, 143, 151, 152, 171, 190, 195. CDL data is from 2010. A comprehensive list of metric creation steps is included in the Processing Steps.
